page.title: 12A Girvan Miner Remembers
page.content: Coal mining is still a dangerous occupation, but was particulary so in the past. One of the reasons for this was the wooden beams which were used to support the roof of the mine. Mr Fyfe a retired miner who worked at Maxwell collery told us the height of the roof changed daily as the timbers moved. Also dangerous were gases such as firedamp and black damp. The former could cause explosions in the shafts, the latter contained no oxygen and suffocated the miners. So to test for gases miners used to carry caged canaries. Mr Fyfe also told us that Romilly pit near Dailly used pit ponies to bring the coal to the surface and when one of the shafts, closed by flooding for 100 years, was opened, the miners discovered bottles shovels and stables
